recordings.loc: Columbia National Wildlife Refuge
recordings.rmk:
For the impatient: 0:04, 1:35, 2:35, 3:52, 5:48

Excerpted from a long dusk recording at an upper marsh in Columbia National Wildlife Refuge. This male spent a few days in this one marshy spot, very slowly pump-er-lunk-ing his way across the pond.

There's a light wind, with a subtle mic buffeting that I've used some creative filtering to minimize. A cricket decided to wake up and gets progressively louder throughout the recording, but it doesn't interfere with the Bittern's call.

recordings.loc: Newlands, BC
recordings.rmk:
- two songs by same adult male.
- extraneous sounds edited by silencing rather than cutting out to preserve time interval between songs.
- bird singing from near east edge of Newlands Marsh, approximately 15 meters north of Upper Fraser Road.
- habitat is fresh water marsh surrounded by mixed deciduous/coniferous forest and grass pastures.
- UTM coordinates of bird from Google Earth: Zone 10U 551928.72 E, 5995802.24 N (WGS84)
- the bittern takes four or five gulps of air to fill his lungs before singing and you can here the bill snapping shut after every intake of air before the booming begins.
- recording device: H2 Zoom; microphone: Sennheiser ME-66; recording is mono even though the H2 labeled the file as stereo.
- sound editing done in Audacity.
- recording available in WAV format upon email request.

recordings.loc: Cheyenne Bottoms, Barton County, Kansas
recordings.rmk: Extended cut of song from bird well-hidden in berm reeds along inlet canal. Multiple silence gaps bridged, some spanning 20 seconds with others as much as nearly 2 minutes. Noise below 100 Hz filtered out.

recordings.loc: Laguna Lake, San Luis Obispo County, California
recordings.rmk:
This American Bittern is likely the same individual as the one I recorded on 3-24-17 with my iPhone and iXY Rode microphone ( XC361329 ), but here I’m using my ME67 Sennheiser  shotgun microphone and PMD 661 Marantz recorder. I used some noise reduction, a high pass filter at 60 dB, and  normalized the volume, but I also reduced the length from a 30 minute recording, with lots of handling noise created as I slowly walked closer, to 3.5 minutes with about 15 seconds between each call. I overlapped each of the 10 calls, fading out and in to blend them.

This bird was in a marshy field, about 100 feet away from me.

recordings.loc: Dairy Mart Pond, San Diego, San Diego County, California
recordings.rmk:
Bird first not visible, in the reeds, by the pond; song unsolicited first. 
We recorded the bird singing with IiPhone and replayed its own song. 
It came closer and became visible, at the edge of the reeds by the water. It kept singing while showing a characteristic behavior, extending its neck while producing the sound.

recordings.loc: Midway Beach, Pacific County, Washington
recordings.rmk: We had heard another individual singing across the beach marshland less than 30 minutes previously, so this bird could be a female, its mate. Flight call as it flushed and flew away from me. Pretty startling, almost stepping on a completely camouflaged Bittern... Anyway, weather cool (~50 degrees F), no wind, overcast. Habitat: beach marshland, probably all freshwater, thick pond vegetation (short reedy grass and whatnot), a few short (~1 m) scrubby deciduous trees. Bird was only 2m away from me when we surprised each other, and I pounded "Record". Short earsplitting click from that was removed at beginning, though a small remnant remains in its first call. Very low high pass filter applied to reduce noise, as recording was amplified (its calls were very quiet, and of course, it was not facing me as it flew away).

recordings.rmk: Flyby bird calling over freshwater marsh shortly after dawn.

recordings.loc: Laguna Lake, San Luis Obispo County, California
recordings.file-name: XC361329-2 American Bittern Laguna Lake iXY 03-24-17.mp3
recordings.rmk: This American Bittern was about 150 to 200 feet away from me between the trail and the lake, in a marshy field, a good 400 feet from the lake. I recorded a total of 7 calls, but only 4 are in this edited version. The calls were an average of every 2 min, 14 sec, ranging from 35 sec to 4 min 19 sec apart.

recordings.loc: Germfask Township (near  Seney), Schoolcraft County, Michigan
recordings.rmk: Heard the bird from the other side of the F Pond, and tracked it by sound to a near location for this recording. Never saw the bird. Voice came from swampy area with cattails, Swamp Sparrows, Red-winged Blackbirds, and other marsh birds. It was clear and sunny at the time of the recording, but clouds were mounting and it rained about an hour later.

recordings.rmk:
Same bird as XC315463 and  XC315750 but without any filter except buzz insect band out around 1.8kHz.
Five calls, 0s, 1:15s, 2:22s, 3:20s, 4:41 and 5:53s, roughly once per minute.
Each time a bloo bloonk-Adoonk bloonk-Ad bloonk-Ad
